Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Andrew M. Zimmer is "Differential Geometry and Dynamics." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Chicago, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Benson Farb.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this postdoctoral research fellowship, the PI spent three years at the University of Chicago as a L.E. Dickson Instructor. The fellowship provided a reduced teaching load which allowed the PI to focus on research, expand his mathematical expertise, write an expository chapter in a textbook, and mentor students.

While supported by the fellowship, the PI produced 13 research articles in pure mathematics. All of these are publicly available on the website arxiv.org and 10 of the 13 have been accepted for publication in the peer reviewed journals: Geometry and Topology (x2), Advances in Mathematics (x2), Mathematische Annalen, Transactions of the American Mathematical Society, International Mathematics Research Notices, Annales de l'Institut Fourier, Geometriae Dedicata, and Indiana University Mathematics Journal. 

The postdoctoral fellowship also allowed the PI to branch out from the topic of his Ph.D. research (differential geometry) and study some classical problems in a totally different field of pure mathematics (several complex variables). The PI also wrote an expository chapter in a recently published book, Metrical and dynamical aspects of complex analysis (Lecture Notes in Mathematics, vol. 2195), explaining how an important concept from in one field of mathematics (geometric group theory) can be used in another (several complex variables). 

Finally, the postdoctoral fellowship also allowed the PI to mentor several students. During the 2014-2015 academic year, the PI worked on a project in differential geometry with a graduate student. This resulted in a paper accepted for publication in the journal Geometry and Topology. In Fall 2015, the PI met weekly with an undergraduate student to discuss topics in differential geometry. In Winter 2017, the PI met weekly with an undergraduate student to discuss topics in topological data analysis.
